OLD LINERS MEET

Gold And Black Superior In
Shorter Running Events

H-OMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 24, 1928

DR. MITCHELL NAMED
BY CLASS OF 1928
Dr. Broadus Mitchell was
elected honorary president of
the senior class, at an election
which took place on Saturday
morning. Numerous other attempts to select this officer had
resulted in a tie between Drs.
Mitchell and Christie, the
engineers and the college men
in the class being equally
divided. The vote was very
close, only a slight margin
separating the two men.

STRENGTH ABOUT EQUAL

PHI BETA KAPPA
ELECTS 9 MEMBERS
Eight undergraduates were
elected to the Phi Beta Kappa
scholastic honorary Society at
Hopkins this year. They are
Sidney Caplan, Aaron Goldstein, Benjamin Fagan, Philip
Margolis, Wesley K. C. May,
William McKnight, Mathew
Debuskey, and Leon Sachs.
The names are listed in order
of their scholastic standing.
Dr. Louis P. Shanks, Associate Professor of Romance
Languages was awarded Phi
Beta Kappa for outstanding
accomplishments in garduate
work.
Phi Beta Kappa was founded at William and Mary
College in 1776. It was
originally a social fraternity
but after a few years it assumed the unique position that
it now holds among honorary
societies in America.

- PRICE 5 CENTS

JAYS DOWNS PENN
IN STEADY RAIN
Blue Jays Set New Record
For Number of Goals
HELFRISH HIGH SCORER
Red and Blue No Match For
Powerful Jay Team

Playing steady, consistent lacrosse
in a constant downpour of rain, the
powerful Black and Blue machine
rolled up a 21-5 score over the University of Pennsylvania twelve for
their third victory of the season.
Hardly once during the game did
the Hopkins club slow up in its
steady scoring; the one possible instance being the beginning of the
second half, when the Penn team •
scored three goals in quick succession.
George Helfrish, playing at first
attack after a year's layoff from the
game, proved to be the bright-light
of the game, scoring eight goals, or
three more than the entire visiting
team made. Logan, Biddison, and
Nixdorf came next in line for number of goals scored, having slipped

EDITORIAL COMMENT

Several men prominent in the field
of colege comics, alumni formerly
connected with the Black and Blue
Jay, and leaders of other campus
activities, were guests at the Black
and Blue Jay banquet, at the Southern Hotel last Thursday night. In
addition to a very interesting program of talks, elections to the several staffs were announced, and
elections for Board of Control positions for next year were held.
The banquet was enlivened by a
three piece orchestra from the
Simpson-Norris organization, who
entertained with music and several
novelty acts. Henry Bussey and the
Blue Jay Trio, who rendered several
selections, completed the program of
entertainment.
Mr. R. B. Fuller, advertising
manager of College Humor, gave an
address stressing the importance of
co-operation between College Humor
and the several college comics for
the mutual welfare of all concerned.
He outlined a program for a constant upward trend in the quality
and quantity of collegiate advertising. Mr. K. N. Sader, who is engaged in the advertising field here
in Baltimore, also gave an address
on this subject.
Gifts Presented

As an acknowledgement for noteworthy service of staff members
during the year, the Board of Control presented cups to Wm. R. McDorman, of the editorial staff; Donald R. Sharrets, of the art staff, and
to George R. Gettemuller of the
business staff. As a token of the
esteem of the Black and Blue Jay,
Leonard Dalsemer, business manager, and Donald W. White, editorin- chief, were presented with gifts.
In the elections following the banquet, Bennett Kolb was elected editor-in-chief for the coming year,
Wm. R. McDorman was elected
managing editor, and Don Sharrets,
art editor. On the Business Board
of Control Richard H. Wood was
elected business manager, George
Gettemuller was elected advertising
manager, Milton Medenback was
elected circulation manager, and Dal
Ghent was elected assistant business
manager.
Prahl was elected to the editorial
staff, Bloom, Kellert, and McDonald
to the art staff, and Ahroon and
Rutherford were named to the business staff.

March 9, 1927
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
I sure get some riled when I see
where some fellow is crowing over
the fact that being older, and having
run into Edgeworth sooner than his
less fortunate compatriots, he challenges the world as the champion
long-time member of the Edgeworth
Club.
He doesn't deserve any medals.
He got his reward in the enjoyment
of his smoking for the added number of years. He was just lucky in
starting sooner, that's all.
However, if you care to delve into
ancient history, look up when they
first started to pull down the old
Grand Central Station in New
York,* then add at least six months
to that, and you will arrive at the
approximate time when I first joined
the club.
I have smoked at least one pipeful of every other tobacco I have
seen advertised, sometimes through
necessity, but most of the time to
prove to myself that I have been
right in sticking to the old blue tin.
Yours truly,
H. M. Wittridge.
*April, 1907.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 24, 1928
DR. M. WALLACE SPEAKS
(Continued from page 4, column 1.)

Feuillerat, edited a definitive collection of his work."
There is little definitely known
about Sir Philip Sidney's life; yet
what we do know reveals him as
looking forward with a great idealism, in an age deeply impressed with
the sense of its superiority, holding
to the chivalry of the past, religious
and patriotic. With him began the
fundamental tradition of English
literature, the tradition that all literature must have a moral purpose.
His reputation, both personal and
literary, is one of the most consistent in history.

day," Dr. Wallace said, "he is still
the president of noblesse and chivalry." Dr. Wallace went on to say
that there has been less tampering
with the heroic character of Sir
Philip Sidney than with any other
national hero. Under the critical
eye of the present generation of
critics he is still the embodiment of
heroism.
Sir Philip Sidney's reputation
began even before his death. His
contemporaries—William of Orange,
Sir Walter Raleigh, Elizabeth—
recognized him as one of the bravest
and best Englishmen of their day.

the business world, a progressive industry—
perfectly satisfied with its own coordination?
This self-criticising viewpoint at Western
Electric has brought together chemist and
mechanical engineer to improve ceramic making methods; mechanical engineer and metallurgist to create new wire-drawing processes;
production engineer and personnel manager to
create new records for stabilized employment.

personal integrity. His life seems camp trip next fall.
to stand out from among his contemporaries as exempt from attack.
"His reputation was as great during
his lifetime as it has been since."
0
M
S
T
It is related that while he was being
carried off the battle field mortally
Convenient and Economical
wounded, a cup of water was offered
him, which he refused in favor of a
TRANSPORTATION
dying soldier of the ranks, saying:
"Thy need is greater than mine."
This story, although told by only
one authority, is generally credited
as being in keeping with Sidney's
life.
Evidence of the high esteem in
which Sidney was held is demonstrated by the men of high rank in
England who claimed his friendship.
He was accounted by some as one
of Her Majesty's (Elizabeth) greatest counselors. "His limitations are
of the kind that do not matter and
only serve to make him more real,"
said Dr. Wallace. "One of the
earliest recorded incidents of his
youth is his order to an accompanying servant to give a shilling to a
blind harpist whom he met on the
road. In the midst of his most
pressing business, Sidney never was
forgetful of an appeal made by the
humble or needy."
"There was an astonishing outpour of letters and elegiac verse on
his death, which was the cause of
widespread grief." Sidney has always been praised for his works.
Milton, who condemned the passage,
Pamelia's prayer in the "Eikon,"
later made amends in his praise of
Sidney's other writings. "In our
own day Sidney is being praised on
both sides of the Atlantic more discriminately perhaps, but certainly no
less enthusiastically."

in scientific test of leading Cigarettes,
James Montgomery Flagg selects

Old Gold
After this test, Mr. Flagg wrote:
"Most of us smoke names and think we are
smoking cigarettes! The blindfold test proved
that to me. It proved also that it is difficult
to tell one cigarette from another...except
in the case of OLD GOLD ... I spotted that
... it suited me best even blindfolded. In
fact, the man who said 'not a cough in a carload' knew whereof he spoke. It's the
smoothness that identifies OLD GOLD. It
needs no other trade mark."

Homage Due to Character

(Continued on Page 3, Column 1)

Viv

The Measure of Oil Value

Blindfolded

"Our homage to Shakespeare is
due to his superb genius," said Dr.
Wallace, "our homage to Sidney, to
his character." During his life his
writings were known only to his
friends, but nothing was published
until his death. Sidney himself regarded his books as trifles, but "Arcadia" is a most authentic witness
to his ability. "Patriotism and
Protestantism were the same to Sidney, who attempted to balance his
work and strike a mean," said the
lecturer, describing this as a typical
English trait. Sidney particularly
reverenced the English lines of descent, and was proud of his own old
family. "There is a satisfaction in
belonging to the same race as Sir
Philip Sidney," concluded Dr. Wallace.
"The reputation of Sir Philip Sidney has suffered less than any other
national character from the powerful iconoclastic force of the present

How Test Was Made
Subject was blindfolded, and, in the presence of
two responsible witnesses, was given one each
of the four leading cigarettes to smoke. To clear
the taste, coffee was served before each cigarette
...Mr. Flagg was entirely unaware of the identity
of these cigarettes during test. After smoking the four cigarettes, Mr. Flagg was asked to
designate by number his choice. He promptly
replied, "Number 2," which was OLD GOLD.

H-OMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 24, 1928

DR. MITCHELL NAMED
BY CLASS OF 1928
Dr. Broadus Mitchell was
elected honorary president of
the senior class, at an election
which took place on Saturday
morning. Numerous other attempts to select this officer had
resulted in a tie between Drs.
Mitchell and Christie, the
engineers and the college men
in the class being equally
divided. The vote was very
close, only a slight margin
separating the two men.

PHI BETA KAPPA
ELECTS 9 MEMBERS
Eight undergraduates were
elected to the Phi Beta Kappa
scholastic honorary Society at
Hopkins this year. They are
Sidney Caplan, Aaron Goldstein, Benjamin Fagan, Philip
Margolis, Wesley K. C. May,
William McKnight, Mathew
Debuskey, and Leon Sachs.
The names are listed in order
of their scholastic standing.
Dr. Louis P. Shanks, Associate Professor of Romance
Languages was awarded Phi
Beta Kappa for outstanding
accomplishments in garduate
work.
Phi Beta Kappa was founded at William and Mary
College in 1776. It was
originally a social fraternity
but after a few years it assumed the unique position that
it now holds among honorary
societies in America.

- PRICE 5 CENTS

JAYS DOWNS PENN
IN STEADY RAIN
Blue Jays Set New Record
For Number of Goals
HELFRISH HIGH SCORER
Red and Blue No Match For
Powerful Jay Team

Playing steady, consistent lacrosse
in a constant downpour of rain, the
powerful Black and Blue machine
rolled up a 21-5 score over the University of Pennsylvania twelve for
their third victory of the season.
Hardly once during the game did
the Hopkins club slow up in its
steady scoring; the one possible instance being the beginning of the
second half, when the Penn team •
scored three goals in quick succession.
George Helfrish, playing at first
attack after a year's layoff from the
game, proved to be the bright-light
of the game, scoring eight goals, or
three more than the entire visiting
team made. Logan, Biddison, and
Nixdorf came next in line for number of goals scored, having slipped

EDITORIAL COMMENT

Several men prominent in the field
of colege comics, alumni formerly
connected with the Black and Blue
Jay, and leaders of other campus
activities, were guests at the Black
and Blue Jay banquet, at the Southern Hotel last Thursday night. In
addition to a very interesting program of talks, elections to the several staffs were announced, and
elections for Board of Control positions for next year were held.
The banquet was enlivened by a
three piece orchestra from the
Simpson-Norris organization, who
entertained with music and several
novelty acts. Henry Bussey and the
Blue Jay Trio, who rendered several
selections, completed the program of
entertainment.
Mr. R. B. Fuller, advertising
manager of College Humor, gave an
address stressing the importance of
co-operation between College Humor
and the several college comics for
the mutual welfare of all concerned.
He outlined a program for a constant upward trend in the quality
and quantity of collegiate advertising. Mr. K. N. Sader, who is engaged in the advertising field here
in Baltimore, also gave an address
on this subject.
Gifts Presented

As an acknowledgement for noteworthy service of staff members
during the year, the Board of Control presented cups to Wm. R. McDorman, of the editorial staff; Donald R. Sharrets, of the art staff, and
to George R. Gettemuller of the
business staff. As a token of the
esteem of the Black and Blue Jay,
Leonard Dalsemer, business manager, and Donald W. White, editorin- chief, were presented with gifts.
In the elections following the banquet, Bennett Kolb was elected editor-in-chief for the coming year,
Wm. R. McDorman was elected
managing editor, and Don Sharrets,
art editor. On the Business Board
of Control Richard H. Wood was
elected business manager, George
Gettemuller was elected advertising
manager, Milton Medenback was
elected circulation manager, and Dal
Ghent was elected assistant business
manager.
Prahl was elected to the editorial
staff, Bloom, Kellert, and McDonald
to the art staff, and Ahroon and
Rutherford were named to the business staff.

Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
I sure get some riled when I see
where some fellow is crowing over
the fact that being older, and having
run into Edgeworth sooner than his
less fortunate compatriots, he challenges the world as the champion
long-time member of the Edgeworth
Club.
He doesn't deserve any medals.
He got his reward in the enjoyment
of his smoking for the added number of years. He was just lucky in
starting sooner, that's all.
However, if you care to delve into
ancient history, look up when they
first started to pull down the old
Grand Central Station in New
York,* then add at least six months
to that, and you will arrive at the
approximate time when I first joined
the club.
I have smoked at least one pipeful of every other tobacco I have
seen advertised, sometimes through
necessity, but most of the time to
prove to myself that I have been
right in sticking to the old blue tin.
Yours truly,
H. M. Wittridge.
*April, 1907.

DR. M. WALLACE SPEAKS
(Continued from page 4, column 1.)

Feuillerat, edited a definitive collection of his work."
There is little definitely known
about Sir Philip Sidney's life; yet
what we do know reveals him as
looking forward with a great idealism, in an age deeply impressed with
the sense of its superiority, holding
to the chivalry of the past, religious
and patriotic. With him began the
fundamental tradition of English
literature, the tradition that all literature must have a moral purpose.
His reputation, both personal and
literary, is one of the most consistent in history.

day," Dr. Wallace said, "he is still
the president of noblesse and chivalry." Dr. Wallace went on to say
that there has been less tampering
with the heroic character of Sir
Philip Sidney than with any other
national hero. Under the critical
eye of the present generation of
critics he is still the embodiment of
heroism.
Sir Philip Sidney's reputation
began even before his death. His
contemporaries—William of Orange,
Sir Walter Raleigh, Elizabeth—
recognized him as one of the bravest
and best Englishmen of their day.

"His reputation was as great during
his lifetime as it has been since."
0
M

It is related that while he was being
carried off the battle field mortally
Convenient and Economical
wounded, a cup of water was offered
him, which he refused in favor of a
TRANSPORTATION
dying soldier of the ranks, saying:
"Thy need is greater than mine."
This story, although told by only
one authority, is generally credited
as being in keeping with Sidney's
life.
Evidence of the high esteem in
which Sidney was held is demonstrated by the men of high rank in
England who claimed his friendship.
He was accounted by some as one
of Her Majesty's (Elizabeth) greatest counselors. "His limitations are
of the kind that do not matter and
only serve to make him more real,"
said Dr. Wallace. "One of the
earliest recorded incidents of his
youth is his order to an accompanying servant to give a shilling to a
blind harpist whom he met on the
road. In the midst of his most
pressing business, Sidney never was
forgetful of an appeal made by the
humble or needy."
"There was an astonishing outpour of letters and elegiac verse on
his death, which was the cause of
widespread grief." Sidney has always been praised for his works.
Milton, who condemned the passage,
Pamelia's prayer in the "Eikon,"
later made amends in his praise of
Sidney's other writings. "In our
own day Sidney is being praised on
both sides of the Atlantic more discriminately perhaps, but certainly no
less enthusiastically."

in scientific test of leading Cigarettes,
James Montgomery Flagg selects

Old Gold
After this test, Mr. Flagg wrote:
"Most of us smoke names and think we are
smoking cigarettes! The blindfold test proved
that to me. It proved also that it is difficult
to tell one cigarette from another...except
in the case of OLD GOLD ... I spotted that
... it suited me best even blindfolded. In
fact, the man who said 'not a cough in a carload' knew whereof he spoke. It's the
smoothness that identifies OLD GOLD. It
needs no other trade mark."

"Our homage to Shakespeare is
due to his superb genius," said Dr.
Wallace, "our homage to Sidney, to
his character." During his life his
writings were known only to his
friends, but nothing was published
until his death. Sidney himself regarded his books as trifles, but "Arcadia" is a most authentic witness
to his ability. "Patriotism and
Protestantism were the same to Sidney, who attempted to balance his
work and strike a mean," said the
lecturer, describing this as a typical
English trait. Sidney particularly
reverenced the English lines of descent, and was proud of his own old
family. "There is a satisfaction in
belonging to the same race as Sir
Philip Sidney," concluded Dr. Wallace.
"The reputation of Sir Philip Sidney has suffered less than any other
national character from the powerful iconoclastic force of the present

How Test Was Made
Subject was blindfolded, and, in the presence of
two responsible witnesses, was given one each
of the four leading cigarettes to smoke. To clear
the taste, coffee was served before each cigarette
...Mr. Flagg was entirely unaware of the identity
of these cigarettes during test. After smoking the four cigarettes, Mr. Flagg was asked to
designate by number his choice. He promptly
replied, "Number 2," which was OLD GOLD.
